sources.text: p. 22. John Hunt, son of Robert Hunt, and Esther Warrington, daughter of Henry Warrington, were married on the Seventeenth Day of ye 3d month 1763
sources.citation: Evesham Monthly Meeting First Book of Marriages, via Ancestry.com search, January 20, 2021

sources.text: p. vi-vii. The oldest son of Robert and Abigail Hunt of Haddonfield Monthly Meeting, John was born in August of 1740.... He and Esther Warrington, daughter of Henry and Elizabeth (Bishop) Warrington, were married on March 17, 1763, under the care of Evesham Monthly Meeting.... By 1766, John was appointed as delegate to Salem Quarterly Meeting.... John Hunt's father, Robert, was a first cousin to John Woolman (1720-1772), journalist and minister. Esther Hunt's nephew, Abraham Warrington, married Rachel Evans, daughter of John Hunt's friend and fellow minister, Joshua Evans.
sources.citation: Hunt, John, “Our Beloved Friend” : The Journals of John Hunt, 1770-1824, 2018

snacControlMetadata.note: Contributors from initial SNAC EAC-CPF ingest

biogHists.text:
John Hunt was born in 1740, the son of Robert and Abigail (Wood) Hunt of New Jersey. His father was a first cousin to the John Woolman (1720-1772). In 1763, John Hunt married Esther Warrington in the Chester meeting house, under the supervision of Evesham Monthly Meeting. He was a Quaker minister for more than 50 years and died in 1824. His memorial, published in 1841, highlighted his public testimony concerning pride and superfluity, and stated that he was particularly concerned with temperance.

From the description of Papers, 1770-1828. (Swarthmore College). WorldCat record id: 57202262

John Hunt's wife Esther Warrington was the sister of Joseph Buzby's wife Hannah Warrington.
John Hunt's wife, Esther Warrington Hunt, was the sister of Joseph Buzby's wife, Hannah Warrington Buzby.
John Hunt was the half-brother of Joshua Hunt, the first husband of Esther Collins (née Roberts).
John Hunt's was the half-brother of Joshua Hunt, whose widow Esther Hunt (née Roberts) married John Collins.
Hugh Cowperthwaite's daughter Phebe married John Hunt's son Benjamin.
John Hunt was the brother of Abigail Hunt, wife of Caleb Evans.
John Hunt was the husband of Esther Warrington Hunt, sister of Elizabeth Warrington Haines Evans.
Enoch Evans was the second husband of Elizabeth Warrington Haines Evans, the sister of John Hunt's wife Esther Warrington Hunt.
John Hunt considered Joshua Evans a dear friend. In addition, Hunt's sister Abigail was the wife of Evans's brother Caleb.

resource.title: Roberts-Hunt family papers, 1677-1829.
resource.abstract: This collection includes papers relating to Rachel H. Roberts and her family. Included is correspondence between Esther Hunt Collins and her first husband, Joshua Hunt, his brother John, her children Elisha, Caleb and Rachel, her second husband, John Collins, and Hannah Yarnall. Also included is correspondence between Rachel H. Roberts and her husband, David. The collection includes genealogical information on the Roberts, Hooton, and other related families, along with wills and account books of Joseph and Susanna Roberts. Letters relate family news, impressions of Redstone Monthly Meeting of Friends, and discussions of Quaker discipline.
resource.displayEntry: Roberts, Rachel H., 1791-1881. Roberts-Hunt family papers, 1677-1829.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.title: Conrow-Hunt Family Correspondence, 1786-1886.
resource.abstract: Contains three letters, 1786-1787, with later manuscript copies, to Quaker minister and diarist, John Hunt, from Darling Conrow. John Hunt added a biographical note concerning Conrow to the final letter. Also contains a letter, 1886, concerning Hunt genealogy.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.title: Hiram Doty collected papers relating to Quaker history
resource.abstract: This collection includes original manuscripts collected by Hi Doty relating to early Quaker involvement in Indian affairs from 1756 to 1821 and the Friendly Association. Of particular interest are documents concerning the settlement at Oneida and the Treaty of Easton. Correspondents include Tedyuscung, Nathaniel Holland, Frederick Post, John Hunt, William Cooper, Israel Chapin, William Savery, James Pemberton, and Joseph Elkinton. Also included in the collection are several letters written by 19th century Quakers on a variety of topics. Among the latter are eight letters received by Joel and Hannah E. Bean.
resource.displayEntry: Hiram Doty collected papers relating to Quaker history, 1756-1874

resource.title: John Hunt papers, 1770-1828.
resource.abstract: John Hunt kept a diary for more than 40 years, recording Quaker concerns and daily events. This collections consists primarily of the manuscript journal, 1770-1800; fragments of 1805, 1806 & 1808; and 1814-1824. Of particular interest are the visits of prominent Quakers, including Elias Hicks and Jonathan Evans. There is also an account book, some correspondence received, and other miscellaneous materials. Correspondents include Ann R. Matlack, Asa Matlack, Elizabeth A. Lippincott, John Cox, Joseph Foulke, and Josiah Roberts.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

resource.title: Papers, 1685-[1919].
resource.abstract: Correspondence, genealogical notes and notebooks, account books, diaries, commonplace books, poetry, map, land records, Meeting records, and other papers chiefly related to the Quaker Matlack, Stackhouse and Roberts families of New Jersey and Pennsylvania; much of collection consists of genealogical material gathered by Asa Matlack (1783-1851) and Asa Matlack Stackhouse (1845-1916) on the Matlack, Stackhouse, Roberts, Romig, Lippincott, Thorn, Heulings, Hunt and related families, includes unpublished mss. "Genealogical notes of the Matlack family ..." compiled by Asa Matlack Stackhouse; correspondence includes approx. 140 letters (1853-1888) of Tacie E. Gillingham chiefly to Robert and Ann R. Stackhouse on family matters; also letters of Elizabeth Roberts Cooper, Ann R. Stackhouse, Ella J. Stackhouse, Mary P. Stackhouse and others; diaries and farm account book of Mordecai Matlack (1808-1896); ledger (1816-1838) of Asa Matlack; commonplace books of Tamar Matlack, Ann R. Stackhouse; travel diary (1807) of Thomas Lippincott. Material related to history of Society of Friends includes records of Chester Preparative Meeting (N.J.), Evesham Monthly Meeting and Chester Monthly Meeting (N.J.), copies of Elias Hicks' letters and extracts of articles about him, copies of writings of John Hunt, also transcripts of "Satan's harbinger encountered ... by C.P. [Caleb Pusey]," (1700) and "George Keith's journal of travels ... on the continent of North America" (1706), map "Meetings within the limits of Philadelphia Yearly Meeting" (1897); published and unpublished mss. of Asa M. Stackhouse on various aspects of western New Jersey colonial history including medicine, Col. Thomas Matlack, Burlington County history; copies of Burlington County (N.J.) land records.

places.note: John Hunt was born, resided, and died near Evesham and Moorestown in Burlington County.
